questions.text: What is the false statement regarding carcinoma larynx?

choices.text: Squamous cell is the most common histological type
Glottis is the most common site
Tobacco is an important causative factor

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is more common in males. 

Laryngeal cancer

  • Male:Female ratio is 10:1
  • Risk factors: Smoking tobacco and alcohol
  • 90-95% are squamous
  • Most common site: Glottis followed by supraglottis and subglottis.

questions.text: Which of the following cancers presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom?
questions.solution:
Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis.

Supraglottic and subglottic growths are often silent. Hoarseness is a late symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Phonotrauma is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma. It occurs due to overuse of voice and is associated with the development of benign lesions such as vocal nodules and cysts.

Hoarseness in supraglottic cancer and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to:

  • Vocal cords with infiltration of the thyroarytenoid muscle
  • Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve
  • Cricoarytenoid joint involvement.

Hoarseness in glottic carcinoma is early because lesions of the cord affect its vibratory capacity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the glottis of the larynx. Which of the following lymph nodes would be initially involved?
questions.solution:
Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords.

However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most common site of cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following laryngeal carcinomas has maximum lymph node involvement?

choices.text: All have equal chances of lymph node involvement

questions.solution:
Supraglottic carcinoma has the highest chance of lymphatic spread in the larynx. 

Lymph node enlargement is often a presenting complaint as it occurs early in the course of the disease.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma limited to the supraglottis. Which of the following subsites will not be affected?
questions.solution:
The Pyriform sinus is not a subsite of the supraglottis.

Epiglottis, false cords, aryepiglottic folds (medial wall of the pyriform sinus), and arytenoids are the subsites of supraglottis.

Aryepiglottic folds are shared between the supraglottis and hypopharynx.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with supraglottic carcinoma. Which of the following lymph node levels is the earliest to be involved?
questions.solution:
Level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most common and earliest nodes involved in supraglottic carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding supraglottic carcinoma?

choices.text: Epiglottis, false vocal cords are most commonly involved
Lymphatic spread to upper and middle jugular lymph nodes
Hoarseness of voice is an early symptom
Bilateral nodes seen in epiglottic cancer

questions.solution:
Hoarseness of voice is a late symptom of supraglottic carcinoma. 

The most common site of supraglottic carcinoma is the epiglottis followed by false cords and then aryepiglottic folds. Nodal metastases occur early to the upper and middle jugular lymph nodes. Bilateral metastases can be seen in cases of epiglottic cancer. Supraglottic growths are often silent as hoarseness is a late symptom.

questions.text: A patient has been posted for a surgical procedure to excise cancerous lesions from the vocal cords. Which laser is most commonly used?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic resection with CO2 laser is most commonly used in laryngeal surgeries.

Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cords can be precisely excised with the CO2 laser under the microscope. It gives the same result as being traditionally treated with radiotherapy. Laser excision has the advantage of lower cost, lower duration of treatment, and morbidity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with complaints of weight loss, hoarseness of voice, and difficulty in breathing. On direct laryngoscopy, a mass involving both the vocal cords with extension to the subglottis is seen. Cords are immobile and there is no lymph node involvement. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glottic carcinoma. What is the next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of glottic carcinoma involving immobile vocal cords with extension to the subglottis suggests that the tumour belongs to the T3 stage. The treatment of choice is concurrent chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

Stage Description
T1 Tumour limited to vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

Treatment of laryngeal cancers:

T stage Treatment
T1a TLM > RT
T1b (mid-cord lesion) RT/TLM > OPL
T2a RT/TLM > OPL
T2b RT ± CT > TLM
T3 CRT
T4a TL> CRT
T4b Palliative management

TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions would you not recommend a total laryngectomy as the treatment?

choices.text: Glottic carcinoma with invasion of the thyroid cartilage
Glottic carcinoma  involving the posterior commissure
Transglottic tumours with fixation of the vocal cords
Tumour involving both vocal cords with normal mobility

questions.solution:
Tumour limited to both vocal cords with normal mobility can be classified as stage T1b. Treatment will include radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery. There is no indication for a total laryngectomy.

Total laryngectomy is indicated in:

  • All T4 lesions
  • Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
  • Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
  • Lesions of the posterior commissureâ€¨
  • Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
  • Transglottic cancers with cord fixation.

It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Treatment of T3 cancers is controversial, open vertical hemilaryngectomy and more extensive partial laryngectomies are used in carefully selected cases. Total laryngectomy or CRT is recommended for bulky T3 tumors or tumors not suitable for conservation laryngeal surgery.

questions.text: In the oncology ward, four patients have been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following patients would you advise for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice?

choices.text: A patient with vocal cord palsy, with subglottic extension
A patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility
A patient with tumor invading the thyroid cartilage
A patient with tumor limited to larynx, with fixed cord

questions.solution:
Among the given options, a patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility will be advised for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice. TNM staging in this patient is T1a.

Option A: TNM staging here is T2b and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.

Option C: TNM staging here is T4a and the patient is advised for total laryngectomy as the first choice.

Option D: TNM staging here is T3 and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice.

T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?

choices.text: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later

questions.solution:
Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland. 

The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure as the definitive management is total laryngectomy.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheostomy

High tracheostomy

  • Done through the 1st tracheal ring
  • An opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland 
  • Done in case of malignancy of the larynx
  • Increased risk of perichondritis and subglottic stenosis

Mid tracheostomy

  • Done through the 2nd - 3rd rings
  • Most commonly done tracheostomy
  • Isthmus has to be retracted or divided

Low tracheostomy

  • Done through the 4th - 5th tracheal ring
  • Done below the isthmus
  • Done when the airway is blocked at an upper airway level
  • Risk of injuring the great vessels of the neck
